newsitem.title: IRAN: Iran awards local firms $260 mln shipbuilding deal.
newsitem.headline: Iran awards local firms $260 mln shipbuilding deal.

text.p: Iran on Tuesday awarded a $260 million contract to build 10 cargo and passenger vessels to three state-run local firms, Iranian media reported.

The deal, between the commerce ministry and the industry ministry, includes six 22,000-tonne cargo vessls, two container ships and two passenger ships, which are to be built over the next 30 months, Tehran radio said.
The daily Kayhan said Arvandan, Sadra, and Sadra International companies, which are controled by the industry ministry, would build the vessels for a state-run shipping firm.
An unnamed Italian company will cooperate with Arvandan to build the passenger ships, two catamarans with a capacity each of 260 passengers and 10 cars, the newspaper said.

Iran has a fleet of 77 merchant ships with a total capacity of 2.2 million tonnes, which carry half of the cargo to and from the country, in addition to a tanker fleet capable of carrying 4 million tonnes of oil a year, according to officials figures.
Tehran plans to replace 44 of the older ships with new vessels during the second Iranian five-year plan which ends in March 2000.
